awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Characterization of Atmospheric Pollen under Weather Extremes
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to evaluate the concentrations and properties of atmospheric pollen particles that rupture under extreme weather conditions.  Pollen fragments can contribute significantly to atmospheric particle number and mass during spring and summer thunderstorms and rain events. There is currently little information about the size-resolved concentrations and properties of pollen fragments in the atmosphere. Because pollens pose significant health risks to populations with respiratory diseases, understanding when and why high levels of pollen fragments occur will serve as a strong scientific basis to protect sensitive populations, through early-warning systems and/or other mitigation strategies.

Field measurements of size-resolved atmospheric pollen fragments will be made in spring and summer in suburban Iowa City IA under a variety of meteorological conditions, leading to a better understanding of exactly when peak concentrations of airborne pollen fragments occur and how long they persist in the atmosphere. Chemical methods will be applied to quantify molecular tracers of pollens in size-resolved ambient particulate matter samples. Optical microscopy will be used to identify intact pollens based on diagnostic traits of size and shape, exine sculpturing, and features of apertures (size, number, and type) using pollen identification keys for the Midwestern United States.  Species of pollen fragments will be identified and quantified using highly-specific enzyme immunoassays in size-resolved particulate matter samples. 
 
This EAGER project is highly exploratory as it seeks to characterize an atmospheric phenomenon of unknown frequency. The project's success depends on the precise occurrence of a combination of seasonal and meteorological factors that are conducive to producing fragmented pollen particles. The potential benefit to be gained from this research is significant, as a better understanding of the conditions under which pollen fragments are formed will enable improved predictions of high allergen content in the atmosphere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
While falling rain removes pollen grains from the atmosphere, rain can also induce pollen rupturing into submicrometer pollen fragments. The objectives of this research study were to assess the seasonal and meteorological conditions that lead to pollen fragments in the atmosphere and to evaluate their atmospheric concentrations and properties. Field measurements were conducted in the Midwestern United States in spring tree pollen seasons of 2019 and 2021 and the summer ragweed season of 2019. Online measurements included single-particle fluorescence spectroscopy, particle number concentrations, and meteorology. Offline measurements included analysis of pollen grain concentrations, chemical tracers of pollen and fungal spores, and bacterial endotoxin.

Pollen fragment concentrations peaked in springtime on high pollen days when convective thunderstorms struck, bringing strong downdrafts, thunderstorm outflows, high rates of rainfall, and numerous lightning strikes. After storms, pollen fragments persisted in the atmosphere for several hours. While major pollen fragment events were rare, low levels were observed throughout springtime on rainy days and did not require lightning for their occurrence. The observed size of pollen fragments, with diameters ranging 0.25 to 2.5 μm, indicates their potential to be inhaled and deposit in the lung at a much higher probability than intact pollen grains. Airborne bacteria were also elevated by thunderstorms, indicating co-exposures to these potentially allergenic atmospheric particles.

Through these field-based measurements, this study has generated new information on the abundance, size distribution, and meteorological drivers of pollen fragments in the atmosphere. This research study has advanced measurement methods to detect pollen fragments in the atmosphere by single-particle fluorescence spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy, and by way of chemical tracers. The broader impacts of this research include the integration of research and training of graduate students and undergraduate researchers, building partnerships for research at the intersection of atmospheric chemistry and public health, and broadening participation of women in STEM.
